Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E-ENG: A Novel Approach for Oceanographic Explorations: Multi-Scale Modeling and Simulation using CFD Enabled by AUVs Data

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to understand the fundamental mechanisms responsible for marine transport through computations that are enabled by data collected through a mobile sensor network. The movement of water provides the energy for geochemical and biological fluxes and occurs over large spatial scales at all ocean depths. Turbulence is a natural characteristic of ocean flows and plays an important role in how materials such as sediment, pollutants and nutrients are dispersed and deposited in the surrounding environment. In spite of the extensive studies, ocean turbulence and the extent to which it influences mass transport processes, such as sediment entrainment and transport, remain poorly understood because of the lack of direct measurements. In this research, a multi-scale modeling and simulation approach using computational models that are data-enabled by specially designed autonomous underwater vehicles will be pursued. If successful, this research will significantly enhance the ocean observations and will enable previously unobtainable measurements.

This project will incorporate recent developments in computational and data-enabled sciences and will combine them with classical work into an innovative educational program at the undergraduate and graduate levels; this interdisciplinary project will emphasize fundamental understanding of the underlying computational and dynamical system processes. UCF's College of Engineering and Computer Science alone has an undergraduate student population of 24 percent minority (African-American, Hispanic, and American Indian) and 14 percent female. This diverse student population enables the recruitment of minority and female students into this project. In addition, through outreach activities supported by this grant, this project will foster an interest in computational and dynamical systems sciences in the broader population and more generally promote an interdisciplinary scientific and engineering culture that will have a long-term impact on all students throughout their careers.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted in this project has led to a number of outcomes. In the context of oceanographic explorations, where spatio-temporal scales vary widely, one outcome was addressing the navigation of AUV (autonomous underwater vehicles) in the uncertain flow field of oceans. An energy optimal control algorithm was developed, where the AUV uses the prevailing flow energy for exploration and thereby reduce its energy expenditure. In this regard, fluid-AUV interactions in smaller spatial scales were incorporated to validate our control design. In addition, guidance of a swarm of AUVs was researched and a continuum-mechanics based approach was formulated to guide the motion of individual AUVs in the swarm, based on commands from a leader AUV. Understanding and modeling of fluid-structure interactions played an important role in this research. To this end, multi-scale computational simulations were conducted to capture the effects of turbulence on dynamically changing interactions. The study  was generalized in this research to incoporate interactions such as that of oil plumes and water, the motion of oil plumes in an oceanic flow field, their disintegration and coalescing, etc. Thus, the overall scope of research was quite broad and multi-disciplinary. It included the main technical aspects that required further research in the field of oceanographic explorations and attempted to integrate these fields. The work opened up a significant scope of further research in this field.

The project provided research opportunities to several graduate students, including women students. It has led a total of three PhD degrees and one MS degrees. It also provided research exposure to undergraduate students. The research topic in each case was unique and provided both depth and breadth of exposure, especially to doctoral students. Students from diverse backgrounds in mechanical engineering, such as ones with expertise in computational fluid dynamics and ones with dynamics and control background, worked together. The research developed a platform for studies of large spatio-temporal fields, such as the oceans or the atmosphere. It will find applications in exploratory efforts such as detection of oil spills, tracking oil plumes, mapping of oceanic or atmospheric currents, mapping of temperature fields, and so on. It will thereby have impact on detection of climate change, detection of impending weather events, etc.


Last Modified: 07/11/2018
Modified by: Tuhin K Das

Images (1 of )
  • Diagram of the feedback control structure. The flow model constructs the flow field based on sensed environmental data from the AUV. The flow model can be CFD based on the complexity of the flow field.
    PhD dissertation: Singith Abeysiriwardena
    Copyrighted
    Tuhin K Das
    Feedback structure for optimal guidance
  • Effect of fluid-AUV interaction during the AUV motion in the flow field toward its destination point. Capturing the interaction helps better estimation of the fluid flow velocities and hence improves guidance.
    PhD dissertation: Singith Abeysiriwardena
    Copyrighted
    Tuhin K Das
    Fluid AUV interaction
  • Time evolution of different modes of breakup for an oil jet in cross-flow water (CFD simulations):Row 1 - dripping, Row 2 - axisymmetric jetting, Row 3 - asymmetric jetting, Row 4 - atomization.
    PhD dissertation: Majid Haghshenas
    Copyrighted
    Tuhin K Das
    Oil jet in cross-flow water
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research conducted in this project has led to a number of outcomes. In the context of oceanographic explorations, where spatio-temporal scales vary widely, one outcome was addressing the navigation of AUV (autonomous underwater vehicles) in the uncertain flow field of oceans. An energy optimal control algorithm was developed, where the AUV uses the prevailing flow energy for exploration and thereby reduce its energy expenditure. In this regard, fluid-AUV interactions in smaller spatial scales were incorporated to validate our control design. In addition, guidance of a swarm of AUVs was researched and a continuum-mechanics based approach was formulated to guide the motion of individual AUVs in the swarm, based on commands from a leader AUV. Understanding and modeling of fluid-structure interactions played an important role in this research. To this end, multi-scale computational simulations were conducted to capture the effects of turbulence on dynamically changing interactions. The study was generalized in this research to incoporate interactions such as that of oil plumes and water, the motion of oil plumes in an oceanic flow field, their disintegration and coalescing, etc. Thus, the overall scope of research was quite broad and multi-disciplinary. It included the main technical aspects that required further research in the field of oceanographic explorations and attempted to integrate these fields. The work opened up a significant scope of further research in this field. The project provided research opportunities to several graduate students, including women students. It has led a total of three PhD degrees and one MS degrees. It also provided research exposure to undergraduate students. The research topic in each case was unique and provided both depth and breadth of exposure, especially to doctoral students. Students from diverse backgrounds in mechanical engineering, such as ones with expertise in computational fluid dynamics and ones with dynamics and control background, worked together. The research developed a platform for studies of large spatio-temporal fields, such as the oceans or the atmosphere. It will find applications in exploratory efforts such as detection of oil spills, tracking oil plumes, mapping of oceanic or atmospheric currents, mapping of temperature fields, and so on. It will thereby have impact on detection of climate change, detection of impending weather events, etc. Last Modified: 07/11/2018 Submitted by: Tuhin K Das
